conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to use the properties of an ideal gas and the relationship between pressure and volume given in the p-V diagram.
The product of pressure and volume is constant along a line in a p-V diagram for an isothermal process, and the ideal gas law is used for other processes.
State A to State B is an isobaric process (constant pressure), and State B to State C is an isochoric process (constant volume).
From the graph, the pressure at state A is \( P_A = 1.0 \times 10^5 \) Pa and the volume is \( V_A = 6 \times 10^{-3} \) m\(^3\).
The temperature at state A is given as \( T_A = 27^\circ C = 300 \) K.
Using the ideal gas law \( P_A V_A = n R T_A \), the number of moles of the gas is calculated as \( n = \frac{1.0 \times 10^5 \times 6 \times 10^{-3}}{8.314 \times 300} \approx 0.238 \text{ mol}.
From the graph, the pressure at state B is \( P_B = 2.0 \times 10^5 \) Pa and the volume is \( V_B = 6 \times 10^{-3} \) m\(^3\) (same as state A).
Since the process from A to B is isobaric, the work done is \( W_{AB} = P_A (V_B - V_A) = 1.0 \times 10^5 \times (6 \times 10^{-3} - 6 \times 10^{-3}) = 0 \text{ J}.
The change in internal energy for an isobaric process is \( \Delta U = n c_V \Delta T \), and since the work done is zero, the change in internal energy is equal to the heat added to the gas.
From the graph, the pressure at state C is \( P_C = 3.0 \times 10^5 \) Pa and the volume is \( V_C = 2 \times 10^{-3} \) m\(^3\).
Since the process from B to C is isochoric, the work done is \( W_{BC} = 0 \text{ J}.
The change in internal energy is \( \Delta U = n c_V \Delta T \), and the heat added to the gas is \( Q = n c_V \Delta T \).
The temperature at state C can be found using the relationship \( \frac{P_C V_C}{T_C} = \frac{P_B V_B}{T_B} \).
